docs.lead_paragraph: Readers discuss an Op-Ed essay that was skeptical about the benefits.

docs.lead_paragraph: Thousands of travelers to the Caribbean and nearby regions are coming home with an unwanted souvenir: a mosquito-borne virus that recently settled there.

headline.main: Caribbean Blues: Mosquito Virus Is Sickening More Travelers
headline.print_headline: Caribbean Blues: Mosquito Virus Is Sickening More Travelers

docs.lead_paragraph: Don’t try to punish them. Just make getting an exemption harder.

headline.main: How to Handle the Vaccine Skeptics
headline.print_headline: How to Handle the Vaccine Skeptics

docs.abstract: Op-Ed article by global health Prof Saad B Omer contends that most effective way to convince skeptical parents to vaccinate their children is to inform them and steer them toward responsible decision, rather than castigating them or eliminating exceptions to vaccination rule; argues states would be best served by allowing exemptions but making them more difficult to obtain, approach that balances individual rights and public health.
docs.snippet: Don’t try to punish them. Just make getting an exemption harder.

docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. Margaret Hamburg, who led the Food and Drug Administration for nearly six years, was praised and criticized for speeding the approval of medicines.

headline.main: F.D.A. Commissioner Leaving After Six Years of Breakneck Changes
headline.print_headline: F.D.A. Commissioner Leaving After Six Years of Breakneck Changes

docs.abstract: Food and Drug Administration Commissioner Dr Margaret Hamburg will step down following six-year tenure leading agency through some significant and challenging issues in public health; Hamburg grappled with painkiller abuse, obesity and the rise of electronic cigarettes, and received both praise and criticism for speeding up the approval of medicines.
docs.snippet: Dr. Margaret Hamburg, who led the Food and Drug Administration for nearly six years, was praised and criticized for speeding the approval of medicines.

docs.lead_paragraph: Several U.S. states are considering laws to make it harder for parents to legally opt out of vaccinating their children, as health officials fight a measles outbreak that has sickened some 120 people in more than a dozen mostly West Coast states.

headline.main: Lawmakers Want Tougher Vaccine Exemptions Amid Measles Outbreak
headline.print_headline: Lawmakers Want Tougher Vaccine Exemptions Amid Measles Outbreak

docs.snippet: Several U.S. states are considering laws to make it harder for parents to legally opt out of vaccinating their children, as health officials fight a measles outbreak that has sickened some 120 people in more than a dozen mostly West Coast states.

headline.main: Doctor, Have You Had Your DNA Tested?

docs.abstract: As a doctor who studies how patients make decisions about genetic testing, I often get asked whether I’ve had my own DNA tested.
docs.snippet: As a doctor who studies how patients make decisions about genetic testing, I often get asked whether I’ve had my own DNA tested.

docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. Margaret Hamburg, who as commissioner of the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) for almost six years has overseen public health initiatives ranging from tobacco control and food safety to personalized medicine and drug approvals, is stepping down, the agency said on Thursday.

docs.lead_paragraph: Federal health regulators on Tuesday approved a highly anticipated medicine from Pfizer Inc. to treat postmenopausal women with a certain type of advanced breast cancer who have not already taken other drugs.

headline.main: Pfizer Breast Cancer Drug Gets Early FDA Approval
headline.print_headline: Pfizer Breast Cancer Drug Gets Early FDA Approval

docs.snippet: Federal health regulators on Tuesday approved a highly anticipated medicine from Pfizer Inc. to treat postmenopausal women with a certain type of advanced breast cancer who have not already taken other drugs.

docs.lead_paragraph: The budget President Obama sent to Congress would establish a coordinated way for researchers to get genetic and clinical data on a million people.
docs.abstract: News Analysis; scientists studying diseases like Alzheimer's, diabetes and cancer are hoping that federal precision medicine plan proposed by Pres Obama will help efforts to understand genetic variation between diseases and develop individual treatments; plan will create coordinated way for researchers to access genetic and clinical data on a million subjects.
docs.snippet: The budget President Obama sent to Congress would establish a coordinated way for researchers to get genetic and clinical data on a million people.
